ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: How to navigate ArcPro, emphasize on raster more so than polygons, inputting data, analyzing data, presenting data
I learned about the basics of ArcGIS and mapping. It was very useful in considering the visual dimensions of data processing and analysis
I learned how to use arcGIS Pro
I learned how to use a lot of tools in GIS and also how to ask questions regarding the use of GIS for whatever I intended to use it for
I developed a strong foundation in ArcGIS Pro. I feel comfortable working with raster and vector layers and think I'll be able to problem solve most GIS problems that come my way.
I gained a good amount of insight on the basic functions of ArcGIS and feel very well equipt to use it on projects in the future, or at least have a very good foundation to keep learning.
Learned how to operate ArcGIS
I learned how to use ArcGIS Pro to create and display geographic information.
I learned how to use ArcGIS Pro, analyze raster/vector data, download GIS-compatible data from various sources, and create presentable maps.
gis i guess
I had never used GIS before, but I feel that I became proficient through this course.
I learned the basics of GIS.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
strengths: professor is an expert and very engaging in class
weaknesses: a lot of learning is done outside of class

I often felt a bit lost in the software and I think I could have probably benefitted from more hands-on engagement both in and out of class to better familiarize myself with the computational analysis.

The course has amazing tutorials for the arcGIS Pro program. They are exceptionally amazing at guiding students to the right direction. That being said, the class is quite unengaging because it is taught to be hands off.

Dana is very available to answer any questions or concerns about the use of GIS, which is great. I think the structure of the course is a big weakness. While we got a little feedback from the first homework assignments, once they began to focus on our final project there was not much feedback at all. So I had no idea whether my project topic/proposed methods were what he expected for a final project.

I loved the homework assignments, I thought they facilitated and aided my learning really well. I also like the grading structure, it took some pressure off to not have grades on the homework. I think there could be a little more direction in terms of content/topic for the final presentation. Lectures were interesting but sometimes it was a little hard to follow ArcGIS being run on the projector, would have preferred just general overviews in class.

Strengths: Professor Tomlin is very knowledgeable and very willing to help students out with their work and helping them get a better understanding of GIS. I also appreciated the course structure, which had well-designed weekly lessons and clear agendas. Professor Tomlin also supplied us with additional materials with well-explained and clear procedures for certain GIS techniques.

Weaknesses: Very little feedback over the course of the semester, and little classroom engagement (every class could have been recorded rather than held in-person). The weekly assignments were often very grueling (more so due to the extremely slow and clunky nature of ArcGIS Pro than how the assignments were designed, to be fair) and took very long to complete.

Dana is very available to his students. He provides really great resources and makes finding out how to do this very straight forward and easily navigated. However, the final project for this course is quite heavy; I feel it is most suited to students who come into the course with data/a project they already know they want to use for this. Proactivity is key. Also did not get feedback from week 8 onward, and would have appreciated a bit more.

Strengths: Good introductory course to ArcGIS

Weakness: Required a ton of independent learning

It's very well organized around student learning and the professor does a great job 
The load in terms of work isn't particularly high but it is pretty time intensive to produce the results you're looking for.

Strengths: meets once a week, helpful handouts for ArcPro tools and processes are given out, professor responds fast to questions, demo/labs can be done on your time instead of through discussion sections or scheduled lab times. 

Weaknesses: weekly assignments do no count towards grades which puts all the weight on the final assignment, feel like you are actively competing against your classmates since prof constantly reminds/emphasizes that our projects are graded relative to one other, you have to be self-motivated in this class or you will fall behind since there aren't graded assignments in place to keep you accountable, you receive feedback on your assignments but in very short email format
tomlin is very smart and funny but the class is.hard

Strengths: You learn a lot through this course. If your goal is to learn GIS and have proof of your skills for internship/job applications, Professor Tomlin will provide you with all the tools you need. 
Weaknesses: I did not feel that our TA was helpful as they did not seem familiar with the assignments we were working on each week. Thankfully, Professor Tomlin is very responsive to questions. This course is also a major time commitment. 6+ hours for weekly assignments and a term project that requires a lot of time during reading week, even if you have been working on parts of it throughout the semester. Please do not take GIS with a heavy course load.

The grading method is somewhat odd and overly stressful as we are compared to our peers. I also think we should get more credit for the homeworks we complete along the way and not have the whole grade be based on the final project.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: i would recommend this class if GIS is a skillset that would be useful for future career aspirations

Yes, if they believe they seriously want to learn arcGIS. The software is messy and extremely tedious to work with. The class occupied more than ten hours a week for me every so often. This takes time and is a difficult class at points.

If you are excited for what you could do for a final project, definitely! I also would recommend this course if you are proactive about getting help/advice from professors as this was something I wish I had done more.
Yes! If you are an environmental studies major GIS is such a good skill to have. This class is interesting and manageable and the software is great.

I don't think I would recommend this class unless it adopted a better assignment feedback system, which is a shame because Professor Tomlin is brilliant and very kind, and ArcGIS Pro is pretty darn cool.
Yes, if you know you require GIS for a project and you have a clear idea of how you want to use it.
Yes, if youre interested in starting off with ArcGIS.
Very much, super informative
If you know you will have a need for ArcGIS Pro in the future, this course is for you.
honestly no. i was hoping to learn a skill, but instead i learned how to google things

Yes, with a few caveats. I learned so much through this course and feel very well-versed in GIS. The final project is also a great product to show to future employers. My first word of warning is to not take this course as part of a 5+ credit semester. Weekly assignments take a long time (6+ hours), and the final took 60+ hours, leaving very little time to sleep or work on other assignments during reading week, even though I started work on my final project during spring break. I was taking GIS as one of four courses. If you take this course, you must ask for help. When you inevitably run into an issue or question, Professor Tomlin is very willing to help and responds quickly through email. Asking for help is absolutely necessary as you do not receive grades/direct feedback on weekly assignments.
Yes if you really really want to learn GIS. There is a certain amount of personal willpower necessary for this course.
